title: How To Train Your Dog To Wait
summary: The first step in getting your dog to wait is to get him to stop following you when you leave the room. It’s important that you don’t physically keep your dog in one place by holding his collar, wrapping a leash around his chest, or using any kind of physical restraint. This can create an association in the dog's mind that you doing this means he should stay put. You can use shaping techniques to help your dog learn to wait for longer periods of time.

content.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:t,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:t,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("h2",null,"The Basics of Teaching a Dog to Wait"),mdx("p",null,"The first step in teaching your dog to wait is to get him to understand the word \u201CWait\u201D. This could be a word you use exclusively for this purpose, or it could be one of the many \u201CC\u201D and \u201CK\u201D words that dogs already understand and we use all the time. Whichever word you choose, you should be consistent about using it for this purpose only."),mdx("p",null,"While you\u2019re working on this training, it\u2019s important that you don\u2019t physically keep your dog in one place by holding his collar, wrapping a leash around his chest, or using any kind of physical restraint. This can create an association in the dog\u2019s mind that you doing this means he should stay put. But if you want to keep him in one place while you\u2019re not there, you\u2019ll need to use a different method that doesn\u2019t give him negative associations with your presence."),mdx("h2",null,"Establishing a \u201CWait\u201D Command"),mdx("p",null,`The first step in getting your dog to wait is to get him to stop following you when you leave the room. The way to do this is to say the word \u201CWait\u201D, and then leave the room.
Once he\u2019s by himself in the room, he will probably start wondering what he\u2019s supposed to do now. It\u2019s at this point that he might start scratching at the door or jumping at it in an attempt to follow you. If he does, praise him and tell him \u201CWait\u201D again, but don\u2019t let him out of the room.
Wait until he\u2019s stopped scratching or pawing at the door, and then go back into the room and praise him again.`),mdx("h2",null,"Reinforcing Behaviors You Like"),mdx("p",null,`Once you\u2019ve gotten your dog to understand the word \u201CWait\u201D and you\u2019ve begun to train him to stay in the room, you can start rewarding him for staying put. Rewarding him can take a number of different forms, but it\u2019s important that you only reward him while he\u2019s waiting, not while he\u2019s scratching at the door.
Wait until he\u2019s relaxed and stopped pawing at the door, and then praise him and give him a small treat.
This can be a great way to reinforce the \u201CWait\u201D command, and it can help him associate the command with something positive.`),mdx("h2",null,"Shaping Behaviors You Want"),mdx("p",null,`As you progress with your training, you can use shaping techniques to help your dog learn to wait for longer periods of time. This process will help him associate waiting with the door or barrier you want him to stay behind and not with you or your actions.
Wait until he\u2019s relaxed and stopped pawing or scratching at the door, and then stand next to the barrier with the treat in your hand and wait again.
When he turns away from the door, even if he\u2019s still waiting and looking in that direction, praise him and give him the treat.
Wait until he turns away from the barrier again, and then repeat.
Once he\u2019s good at this, you can start introducing other distractions that are happening in the room with him.`),mdx("h2",null,"How to Build on What You\u2019ve Taught So Far"),mdx("p",null,`Once you\u2019ve gotten your dog to understand that he should stay in the room and not follow you when you leave, you can start adding new behaviors to the process while keeping the other ones consistent.
Once he\u2019s waiting by the door or barrier, you can walk away from him and give him the \u201CWait\u201D command.
When he turns away from the door and starts to follow you, tell him \u201CWait\u201D again with a slight pause between the two words.
Wait until he turns away from the door again and then praise him and let him follow you.
Continue this process until he\u2019s good at following you while remaining in the room.`),mdx("h2",null,"Wrapping Up"),mdx("p",null,"As you continue working with your dog, you can start to add more distractions to the process, such as having people in the room or having other dogs with him. You can also start experimenting with new environments and see how your dog does waiting in other places."),mdx("p",null,"The important thing to remember is that you must be consistent with your training and you must reward your dog for doing what you want him to do. If you don\u2019t, you\u2019ll find that you\u2019ll get nowhere with your training, and your dog may even stop following the \u201CWait\u201D command you\u2019ve already taught him."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Deal with a Partner Who's Always on Social Media

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`According to recent analysis by Statista, the average millennial spends almost one hour every day on social media. That\u2019s not just posting pictures and updating our profiles, but also lurking on other people\u2019s profiles. The rise of dating apps like Tinder, Bumble, and Happn has only hastened this tendency. In fact, an article in Fast Company suggests that millennials are so preoccupied with online dating that they now spend more time on it than on any other leisure activity besides watching TV or listening to music.
On top of all this, many couples now meet their partners online \u2013 a third of marriages in the U.S. start with either partner meeting their future spouse through an online dating site or app. While it\u2019s easy to feel pressured into signing up for these services if you don\u2019t have friends who are single and looking for love, being in a relationship with someone who does use them regularly can be challenging at times.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Deal with a Partner Who's Always Travelling
How to Get Out of a Style Rut

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"The risk of falling into a style rut is something we all have to deal with from time to time. It happens to even the most confident and daring of people, so you\u2019re certainly not alone if you feel like your style is stagnating and you can\u2019t think of anything new or exciting to wear. Whether it\u2019s because you haven\u2019t found a new piece of clothing that excites you in months, or because you just don\u2019t know what to wear after wearing variations on the same theme for several weeks in a row, everyone gets stuck in a rut now and again. Thankfully there are ways to get out of it and discover a new lease on your personal style once again."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 10 Easy Tips for Sticking to Your New Year's Resolutions

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"New Year\u2019s resolutions are like a clean slate for the coming year. What you do with that opportunity is up to you. Maybe you resolve to eat healthier, exercise more or reduce stress and anxiety. Maybe you decide to learn a new skill, read more books, help others or travel more. Or maybe your resolution is to do something completely different \u2014 like learn a language, stop procrastinating or read the complete works of Shakespeare. The possibilities are endless, but sticking to those resolutions can be challenging. The key is establishing habits that will last all 365 days of the year and not just one crazy day in January. It takes small but deliberate changes in everyday life that add up over time and become second nature. Here are 10 easy tips for sticking to your New Year\u2019s resolutions:"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Train Your Dog to Come When Called

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Do you have a well-trained dog? If not, are you looking for a way to improve? Coming when called is an essential command that most pet owners neglect. When your dog comes when called, it means he will come back to you right away and not run away or chase something else. This will help keep your dog safe, especially if he\u2019s prone to running away or chasing objects or other animals. It also helps with training and makes everyday interactions much easier than having to constantly chase after your pet.
But perhaps the most important reason why you should train your dog to come when called is because it might just save his life one day. In many cases, dogs that run away don\u2019t get lost, they are just trying to find a way back home. Therefore, knowing how to train your dog to come when called can be the difference between him coming home safe and sound or getting lost forever. And let\u2019s face it \u2013 nobody wants that!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Stay Organized and Sane as a Busy Mom
From First Date to Soulmate: How to Know If You're on the Right Track

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`There are so many first date horror stories out there \u2014 awkward silences, strange amateur- magician tricks, and cringe-worthy pick-up lines being just a few of them. But getting past these awkward initial stages and finding a potential partner who you can connect with on a deeper level is no mean feat. Figuring out if someone is your soulmate or simply the first step to becoming one isn\u2019t easy. Even though it can feel like we\u2019re constantly being bombarded with images of fairy tale love and meet-cute romances, dating in real life isn\u2019t always so straightforward. Unless you\u2019re living under a rock, you probably know that letting somebody into your private world isn\u2019t something to take lightly.
But how do you know if you\u2019re on the right track when it comes to dating? Whether you\u2019ve just met someone new and want to get to know them better without rushing things or have been seeing somebody for some time and are wondering if they could be The One, here are some signs that could indicate that this person may be more than just a casual partner\u2026`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Deal with a Partner Who's Always on Their Computer

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`When you enter into a relationship with another person, you\u2019ll naturally want to spend as much time together as possible. It can be super easy to fall into a routine when you\u2019re spending so much time with each other. You go to work, come home, and then retreat to your respective rooms for the rest of the night. And while that routine is totally normal and understandable at this stage in your relationship, it might not be exactly what you\u2019re looking for.
It\u2019s easy to get jealous or resentful if your partner is always on their computer \u2014 but that doesn\u2019t mean that there isn\u2019t a reason for their constant use of it. It could be that they are really passionate about something they\u2019re researching online or maybe they have an online business venture they\u2019ve been working on for a while now. However, if this is causing tension between you two, speak up! They may not even realize how much time they spend on their computer and just how much of an impact it has on your relationship. Here are some ways to deal with a partner who's always on their computer:`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Deal with a Partner Who's Always on Their Phone

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Now and again, your significant other will probably spend more time with their phone than with you. After all, it\u2019s 2018, and smartphones are practically a necessity for anyone who wants to stay connected. But if your partner is glued to their cell 24/7, it can obviously become a source of tension between you two. It\u2019s natural to feel a little jealous when someone you care about spends more time texting than talking with you, after all. And this is especially true if they seem to be ignoring you while they do so.
If your partner always seems to be on their phone, there could be several explanations \u2014 from an online affair to simply being an avid social media user. Regardless of the reasons why your partner might spend so much time on their phone, though, the way that you react definitely matters. Being insecure and accusatory about something as innocent as checking messages isn\u2019t likely to lead anywhere positive, after all. Here are some tips for dealing with a partner who\u2019s always on their phone:`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
